channel.title: YOUR usage of Dropbox (And why you could be better off...)
channel.description:
[center][img]http://i.imgur.com/jl5CX.png[/img][/center]
[size=18pt]The Problem[/size] I have noticed that nearly everyone here uses Dropbox. Dropbox is good, I personally use it for synchronizing relatively important things between various machines, and it does a very good job. [i]It's made to be good[/i]. The job Dropbox is made for is synchronizing files between computers seamlessly, so you're always up to date on what you have. However, you don't need detailed information about a file's history and changes; the average user of Dropbox doesn't need a detailed backlog, and so Dropbox does not provide it. The average user will also rarely, if ever need to edit on two different machines simultaneously, so there's no real support for that either.
However! Programming is something that can go wrong very quickly, and a good way to fix things is to have a history. It's also very annoying if you're a programmer and two people working on one thing end up clashing and causing lots of errors. The manual solutions to these problems are:
[ul][li]Keep a backup of a working copy to revert or refer to if things go wrong[/li] [li]Coordinate what people are working on through Skype or MSN[/li][/ul]
Both of these solutions will work, provided you're attentive and willing to coordinate lots of development precisely, but in all honesty, [b]wouldn't you just love it if this was all done for you?[/b]
[size=18pt]The Solution[/size] Enter: [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Revision_control]Version Control Systems (VCS)[/url]. They do everything for you, such as keeping backups and storing development history and allowing multiple people to work on the same project seamlessly and easily. Imagine how much faster your programmers will be able to work if they're not constantly having to coordinate their work; they just write code and submit it. Also, a good VCS will prevent people from sabotaging your project and causing damage.
There are lots of different types of VCS, the commonest being [b]Subversion (SVN)[/b] (http://subversion.apache.org/) and [b]Git[/b] (http://git-scm.com/).
[center][table] [tr] [td][size=15pt]SVN[/size][/td] [td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td] [td][size=15pt]Git[/size][/td] [/tr] [tr] [td]Easy to understand, closer to Dropbox[/td] [td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td] [td]Harder to understand but more flexible[/td] [/tr] [tr] [td]Lots of contributors can be harder to manage[/td] [td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td] [td]Very easy to manage lots of contributors[/td] [/tr] [tr][td][b]Project Hosting[/b][/td] [td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td] [td][b]Project Hosting[/b][/td] [/tr] [tr] [td] [url=http://www.assembla.com/]Assembla[/url] [url=http://sourceforge.net/]SourceForge[/url] [url=http://code.google.com/hosting/]Google Project Hosting[/url] (Open source only) [/td] [td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td] [td] [url=https://bitbucket.org/]Bitbucket[/url] [url=https://github.com]GitHub[/url] (Free for open source; Good community) [url=http://www.assembla.com/]Assembla[/url] [/td] [/tr] [tr] [td][b]Where To Start[/b][/td] [td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td] [td][b]Where To Start[/b][/td] [/tr] [tr] [td] [url=http://www.shokhirev.com/nikolai/programs/SVN/svn.html]SVN with TortoiseSVN[/url] (A nice interface for SVN) [url=http://maverick.inria.fr/Membres/Xavier.Decoret/resources/svn/index.html]SVN for UNIX[/url] (Gives a good command-line overview) [url=http://svnbook.red-bean.com/]Version Control with Subversion[/url] (Highly regarded) [/td] [td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td] [td] [url=http://creatingcode.com/2010/02/getting-started-with-git-and-tortoisegit-on-windows/]Git on Windows with TortoiseGit[/url] (A nice interface for Git) [url=http://help.github.com/]GitHub's Git Setup guide[/url] (Incredibly comprehensive) [url=http://progit.org/book/]Pro Git[/url] (A really good ebook) [url=http://book.git-scm.com/]Git Community Book[/url] [url=http://sixrevisions.com/resources/git-tutorials-beginners/]A List of Good Tutorials/Books[/url] [/td][/tr][/table] [/center]
[size=18pt]VCS Plugins for IDEs[/size] Most Java IDEs have support for version control systems provided as plugins or integrated into the IDE, which are a very useful and convenient way of developing and collaborating.
[center] [table] [tr] [td][b]Eclipse[/b] SVN: [url=http://www.eclipse.org/subversive/]Subversive[/url] | [url=http://subclipse.tigris.org/]Subclipse[/url] Git: [url=http://www.eclipse.org/egit/]EGit[/url][/td] [td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td] [td][b]Netbeans[/b] SVN: [url=http://netbeans.org/kb/docs/ide/subversion.html]Integrated SVN[/url] Git: [url=http://nbgit.org/]NBGit[/url][/td] [td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td][td][/td] [td][b]IntelliJ IDEA[/b] SVN & Git: [url=http://www.jetbrains.com/idea/features/version_control.html]Integrated VCS[/url][/td] [/tr] [/table] [/center]
[size=18pt]Teams, Leaking and Sabotage[/size] There are certain common problems that by purely using a VCS will not be solved, such as source leaking, which is a frustrating problem and a difficult one to counter. To prevent your source being leaked, it is highly recommended that you take care in selecting people to be on your team, perhaps quizzing them on why they want to be a part of your project. Unfortunately, there is no real way of preventing source leak, and occasionally you will get someone who wants to hinder the movement and productivity of your team by leaking or deleting source code. In the latter case, VCS software prevents source code being lost by keeping local copies of the source on your project member's computers, so deletion of the source should not be a large obstacle for your team to overcome since restoration is easy. You also have a lot of control over what source code is submitted to your projects so it's easy enough to avoid accepting the source with bits missing.
[size=18pt]Final Musings[/size] Unlike Dropbox, learning to use a VCS will take longer. They are more complex, but a lot more flexible and much more reliable, and fortunately people have seen the need to help people with the complexity, hence why you'll find many tutorials about various VCS systems written for beginners.
Perhaps you may ask why your part-time 2-man project needs a VCS, truthfully it probably won't, but many projects are more than that, yet they still use technologies that are unfit for the task, and since I've seen a few projects in this situation, I decided to create this to help out those who are having problems.

The issue does seem to be more about people stealing and releasing sources, not the repositories. So if you could implement or rephrase that part of the post in put it in as well, that would be nice

[quote]Many members of this community, specifically the members who work with a team are getting screwed by others. The main reason is from bringing people who don’t know what they are doing into their team. Once you are guilty of this you have the issue of not getting things done right and also frustation; which then leads to a leaked source.

To combat the leaking problem you can simply test people who want to be apart of your team. By test I mean ask them how they would do ‘this or that’. If they are unsure of how to complete the simple test or don’t produce satisfactory results don’t let them join your team. It’s really as simple as that, if you take the time to choose the correct members you will not only prevent a leak but you will succeed with your goals.

The next issue I see a lot of is a source being deleted by that one team member who just decides to be an ass. Once this happens you are, to be blunt: shit out of luck. Below is a list of repository products that give each member of the team a local copy of the files, so if someone deletes the files you won’t see the effect unless you pull that change. Incase you do pull though these products will allow you to revert back to any state of the server you wish. Each ‘state’ is called a revision and at any point you can revert back to any revision you wish. All of that is as simple as a click of the mouse.[/quote][/quote]
i’ll add more about teams and leaking when i have some spare time. thanks!

item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

I think the more useful part of the other sticky was the paragraphs about teams, not version control (which is why I said to you on IRC I didn’t think this should replace the other sticky). The issue does seem to be more about people stealing and releasing sources, not the repositories. So if you could implement or rephrase that part of the post in put it in as well, that would be nice

Many members of this community, specifically the members who work with a team are getting screwed by others. The main reason is from bringing people who don't know what they are doing into their team. Once you are guilty of this you have the issue of not getting things done right and also frustation; which then leads to a leaked source.

To combat the leaking problem you can simply test people who want to be apart of your team. By test I mean ask them how they would do ‘this or that’. If they are unsure of how to complete the simple test or don’t produce satisfactory results don’t let them join your team. It’s really as simple as that, if you take the time to choose the correct members you will not only prevent a leak but you will succeed with your goals.

The next issue I see a lot of is a source being deleted by that one team member who just decides to be an ass. Once this happens you are, to be blunt: shit out of luck. Below is a list of repository products that give each member of the team a local copy of the files, so if someone deletes the files you won’t see the effect unless you pull that change. Incase you do pull though these products will allow you to revert back to any state of the server you wish. Each ‘state’ is called a revision and at any point you can revert back to any revision you wish. All of that is as simple as a click of the mouse.
